content.description:
Sit start with the left-hand in an incut crack on the steep overhang, and the right hand on a flat sloper on the arete. Pull onto the wall and make a hard right-hand move up the arete to a decent pinch with a good pocket thumb catch. Squeeze hard and get some higher feet before figuring out how to snag one of the sharp crimps on the roof with the left-hand. After the left-hand move to the crimp, make another powerful right-hand move up the arete. From here, reach for the jug lip with either hand and core up to prevent the almost inevitable dab. 

 A jump start from low under the roof with the pocket right-hand pinch to the lip jug has been done without dabbing the rock behind somehow. This leads me to believe that skipping the sharp left-hand crimps on the roof is potentially a possibility for a monster with incredible power and pinch strength and some serious core.
content.protection: 3 pads. Bring a thin one or potentially ditch one of them depending on your beta.
content.location: Start under the obvious lowball roof, on obvious holds.

content.description:
Sit start under the short roof with the right-hand low on the sloping arete and the left-hand in a crack feature on the overhang. Pull onto the wall and make a powerful right-hand bump move directly up to a sharp crystal crimp about a foot above the right starting hold. From here figure out how to power out from under the roof and go for the lip. Match the lip then top out on to the large flat platform of the boulder.

 This problem is less dabby than its harder counterpart which potentially makes it the better line.
content.protection: 2 pads and a spotter. The landing has two tiers.
content.location:
This boulder is located to the right of a large clam-shaped boulder with an awful landing. 

 This problem is the direct way from under the roof, while The Seismic Project follows the arete up via a few powerful moves and your choice of stupid hard dyno to a jug or a desperate lefthand deadpoint to a few sharp crimps on the overhang.

content.description: This is a large flat boulder lying near the top of the talus covered hill in The Amazon. The most prominent line revolves around an aesthetic 65-degree overhanging lowball-arete on the South-East face, which hosts some of the steepest and most powerful moves in the Park. Apart from this burly project, there are a few more problems found on this boulder. Although the problems are short, they are powerful and fun, nonetheless.
